speech.p: I draw to the attention of the witnesses that, when giving evidence from within the parliamentary precincts, they are protected by absolute privilege in respect of the evidence they give to the committee. This means that a witness has a full defence in any defamation action for anything said at the committee meeting. However, witnesses are expected not to abuse the privilege and may be directed to cease giving evidence at the issue of the Chair's direction. Witnesses should follow the direction of the Chair in this regard. They are reminded of the long-standing parliamentary practice to the effect that, as is reasonable, no adverse commentary should be made against an identifiable third person or entity. Witnesses who are giving evidence from a location outside the parliamentary precincts are asked to note that they may not benefit from the same level of immunity from legal proceedings as a witness giving evidence from within the parliamentary precincts and may consider it appropriate to take legal advice on the matter. Privilege against defamation does not apply to the publication by them, outside of the proceedings of the committee, of any matters arising from the proceedings.

On the agenda for this session, we are staying with anaerobic digestion. The committee will hear from officials from the Department of Climate, Energy and the Environment: Mr. Seán Kinsella, principal officer, and Ms Niamh Hamill, assistant principal. Their opening statement has been circulated. I will give them five minutes to read it and we will then proceed to questions from members.
I thank the committee for the opportunity to discuss with it the topic of anaerobic digestion. I will be representing the chair of the biomethane implementation group.

Ireland is recognised as having one of the largest potentials for biomethane production in Europe per capita due to Ireland’s substantial agricultural sector. Biomethane can bring multiple benefits, including emission reduction in the energy sector; reduced agriculture sector emissions through diversification opportunities for livestock farmers; reduced emissions from animal by-products; and replacement of chemical fertiliser with bio-based fertiliser. A domestic biomethane sector can stimulate the rural economy as most biomethane production is envisaged to occur in rural Ireland due to the nature of feedstock required. It also improves national gas security and diversification of supply. Government has committed to supporting a production level of 5.7 TWh of indigenously produced biomethane per annum, which equates to approximately 10% of current gas demand in Ireland.

Delivery of this ambitious target will require the development of an anaerobic digestion sector at scale. A first key step in this regard was the development and publication of the national biomethane strategy in May 2024. The strategy sets out a pathway to address the challenges in achieving target delivery and outlines the necessary supports and policy enablers needed to drive growth across the biomethane sector. Shortly after the publication of the national biomethane strategy, the biomethane implementation group was established. The group is chaired by the Department of Climate, Energy and the Environment, with the close support of the Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine, reporting to the heat and built environment task force. The biomethane implementation group consists of representatives from relevant Departments, State agencies and semi-State companies, which bring their respective expertise to the sector and have specific responsibility for implementation of individual actions set out in the strategy.

While anaerobic digestors used to produce biomethane can bring significant benefits to the communities and local environment in which they are located, they are also significant infrastructure. Important deliverables under the national biomethane strategy include actions that will see the development of planning guidelines to support local authorities when assessing anaerobic digestion plants, and a communication strategy to ensure information on the sector is readily available for all stakeholders, notably, local communities in the vicinity of where anaerobic digestion plants are potentially being built.

The anaerobic digestion sector is regulated through a number of State agencies and Departments. To meet Ireland’s target of 5.7 TWh of biomethane production, the required anaerobic digestion developments and related infrastructure are subject to consent, including but not limited to planning permissions, licences and permits approved by the Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine, the Environmental Protection Agency, the local authority or An Coimisiún Pleanála, as applicable. Anaerobic digestion and other integrated assets are required to undergo a planning process to ensure proper consideration of a range of factors, including location, visual impact, land zoning plans and ecology.

The implementation group has also developed an environmental sustainability charter. By following the best practices outlined in this document, operators, farmers, engineers, planning consultants, design engineers and developers demonstrate their commitment to maximising the benefits and valorisation of anaerobic digestion and bio-based products, while minimising its environmental impact, improving water quality and ensuring high-quality safety standards.

The biomethane implementation group is working hard to implement the 25 actions set out in the national biomethane strategy and is fully committed to the development of an anaerobic digestion sector that can maximise the benefits for Ireland, while ensuring it adheres to best practice and benefits all stakeholders. We are happy to answer any questions members may have on the national biomethane strategy and the implementation of the 25 actions it sets out.

I welcome the officials from the Department. I presume they watched the witnesses last week who were pro this. This evening, we had those who - I will not say anti - were a little more cautious about the whole thing. There was a big difference of opinion. Mr. Kinsella finished on the matter of water quality. Maybe he can be the judge and jury on where the axe comes down between the two.
On regulation of the sector, it is a highly regulated sector. You need to go through full planning permission, you need to get licences or permits from the Department-----

I am sorry to interrupt, but the people who are just gone said that while the EPA regulates it to an extent, the EPA does not have the powers. While it might be regulated, those witnesses seemed to think the EPA, even if it found a fault, does not enough power when it comes to finding for breaches of conditions or whatever.

I am not sure about whether it is enough. The EPA has powers. It has not raised any issues in relation to the level of powers it has with the implementation group but, if that is an issue, we are happy to hear about it and to engage with the EPA. The EPA is ultimately an independent agency on behalf of Government. We have limits on what we can say in relation to that as well.
I appreciate that but I am-----
We are happy to take that feedback and feed it back to the EPA.
-----saying what they said.
I will add to that. There is another key point. The length of time to handle enforcement issues was mentioned. Resourcing is a key-----
Sorry, I cannot hear you at all.
I will lean in. You will have to hear me shouting now.

Resourcing is a key issue. While it is a heavily regulated industry, it is called out in the strategy whether agencies are resourced enough to handle the level of applications that are going to be coming through. There are two sides to that. One is we have to help them to standardise that assessment process and make sure they are resourced to do it. Then, as the industry starts to grow at scale, we need to see whether that is adequate and whether it is there. The timelines for process enforcement issues were mentioned. That could be seen as a resourcing issue as well. It is not that the EPA does not have the powers, but how long it is taking to process. There are a couple of things. The strategy calls it out that we need to look at resourcing. That is a key action we are working on with the EPA and the Department of agriculture regarding animal by-products as well. Whether it is licensing, permitting or the whole works, it is about resourcing.

Even with the regulation in place, engagement must happen with local communities. This sector will not develop unless we have local communities on board. The developers working on these projects must respect the local communities where the plants are going to be operating. They must engage with those local communities. We heard from previous witnesses that they tried some of that engagement but it was not necessarily correct. We are looking to develop a communications strategy for the implementation and development of the sector. One of the key elements will be to establish best practice for engaging with communities. We are aiming to set that out in the near future.
Would community engagement be obligatory?
Yes.

The Senator asked if we are the judge or jury. We are the middle ground. We are the place between the two. Developers need to engage the communities. Anyone who is going to have to live beside the plants needs trust and a source of information. We see ourselves as that, rather than judge or jury.

If the witnesses were in my seat and I was in theirs, what would the Department like us to do? It can only enforce the legislation that we bring forward. If I were in the witnesses' seat and they were in mine, what would they be asking of me?
The strategy is there. All the policy that is needed is there. It is now about implementation and working through those 25 actions set out in the strategy.
It is down to the Department.

It is down to us and the owners of those 25 actions we are working through at the moment, including the various Departments and State agencies, semi-State companies, regulators, etc. They all have ownership of the various actions. They are all there. We just need to implement them.
The previous group of witnesses were looking for regulations. How would the Department compare and contrast the regulations that those witnesses were looking for and what is already in place?

As a starting point, we are looking to scale the industry. We are at a low starting point with the number of plants we have. The actions we have are starter actions. As was mentioned, different local authorities in different areas are assessing the plants and we need a standardised approach and guidance. They need to be able to see what is best practice, what they should be looking at and what types of plants should be coming in. That is the first key action we are taking.
Going back to the question, is that a body of work for the Department or for us?
It is for the key Government Departments, including the Department of housing and our Department, which has oversight, and for any key agencies that are involved. There are a few.
The Department can do it and does not need political-----

Not at this point of the process, no. Whether the powers are strong enough has been touched on. At the start, we need to standardise and offer support and resources. We will then be able to answer that question. Right now, we see the issue as more around standardisation and resourcing. We have the power to do that part.

I thank the witnesses for coming in. Concerns would be raised about regulation in the area of planning. You could get a planning decision for you in one place and against you in another. Are there specifics for proximity to roads or set-back distances from houses, no more than there are for wind turbines? Is the Department looking at anything in that regard? The witnesses can answer that before I go to the next question.

The action within the strategy is that we develop guidelines for planning. We started engagement with the Department of housing in that regard. Biomethane is recognised in the national planning framework and the Planning and Development Act. It is in there already. What we need to look at for guidelines is pulling all those various elements together to ensure local authorities have that information to hand.
Are those guidelines there for us to look at?
Yes. There is one in-----
I mean the guidelines the Department is developing.
The guidelines as per the actions are in development. They still need to be developed.
Can the committee see them?
We are still developing them.

In its submission, the Department referred to grasslands moving to alternative uses. I have followed that idea for a good while. I understand that slurry and chicken litter are pretty good options. The committee was out with An Bord Bia, which stated it could not afford to pay for grass coming into it. I would not be an admirer of too much grass cutting because we need it for cattle. If I want to build an AD plant in the morning, what support will I get from the Department?

I know that issue came up in the previous meeting and the one before that. The renewable energy directive sets out strict requirements for the production of gas for it to be determined as sustainable. That includes that there cannot be any impact on food security. There is a certain level of the amount of energy crops that can go into gas production.

In the strategy, and I may be a little off with my figures, approximately 0.8 TWh, up to approximately 1.5 TWh, of that 5.7 TWh will be waste based. That is already there and available. Once you try to move up to get to the 5.7 TWh, you have to shift into agriculture. The heat study was where that target was found. That was based on land that is already there and available. It was not about changing practices but maximising practices that are already in place so there would be no impact in that regard.

I do not buy that with the Department. In studying AD, you need grass at a certain height. We are not going to go into every 5 acre field for 40 miles around and pull 5 acres. You have to have 500 or 600 acres that you cut in one go, in a second go and a third go. At a certain height, a contractor is appointed. That is taking grass out of production, to be quite frank about it, no matter how you dress it up. If I wanted to build an AD plant in the morning, what funding can the Department give?
The national biomethane strategy has looked at two support mechanisms for the development of AD plants. The first is grants. The Department of agriculture-----
How much? That is what I am asking.
It was 20% of the build, to a maximum of €5 million. That was the first grant.
How much of a purse is there?
A purse of €40 million. That was from-----
That would mean eight per year. Is that correct?
No. Eighteen projects were allocated funding under that first grant.
Some of them were smaller. Is that right?
That is exactly right.
They range in size.

In the line of the farmer-led one, Mr. Seán Finan was before the committee. Mr. Brendan Gildea is near my neck of the woods. He has built one and it is impressive. The fund for that looks to be very low. Is there €3 million or €4 million available? How is it that the Department does not encourage more of that?

There is an action. The strategy was obviously developed in partnership with the Department of agriculture. It was for that reason. It was not seen as wholly an energy project. It was seen as also including feedstock production. There is an action in there around small-scale operations-----
I am on about the budget.
-----and looking at what supports might be needed.
How much is the budget?
There is no grant at the moment as far as I know. That is what is being looked at to actually-----
There is no grant.
Not on the small-scale side.

It is open to all AD developers but there were limited small-scale ones in the first grant round. For the second grant round, funding was secured by the Minister, Deputy O'Brien, in the recent budget. We will consider how we can support or encourage the building of more farm-based AD plants. We will look at that percentage and consider if we can up it.
The Department is generally looking at large-scale projects. Is that right?
No, it is open to all AD developers at all scales.
It is just that we see there is going to be a specific need for farm-led and smaller-scale projects. It is a whole different model and needs a tailored grant. There is an action included to do that.
Is there an obligation coming in, under the climate action plan, that 10% of all gas will have to be renewable?
The renewable heat obligation.
Am I right that the Department has some dream of importing some of that? Is that right?
No. At the moment, the obligation would be open and the supplier can choose to meet it. The obligation obviously has-----
Can it be brought in from abroad?
At the moment, because we are operating in the Single Market for EU trade, that would have to be allowed. However, the obligation has a second aim to support indigenous fuels.

Would the witnesses agree that it needs some bit of a poke or help if at the moment, it is 4 cent per KWh, as against roughly 16 cent per KWh? That is a huge difference. Would they think there is a need for more Government funding to entice it? People vote with their feet. I know there is an obligation coming in. When is it coming in?
The heads of Bill have been approved by the Government. We are now into the drafting stage. We are looking to have this implemented as early as possible in 2026.
When is that roughly? Will it be 2030?
No, 2026. We are trying to capture as much of 2026 as possible.
The obligation will be on every company.
Fuel supplier.

The way the witnesses are talking, they seem to be thinking there is going to be an influx of this. They are expecting a lot of applications in. Would the timeframe for it not be sooner rather than later?

Ultimately, what these developers need to get these plans built and for their business model to stack up is the renewable heat obligations scheme, RHO, which will place a demand on fuel suppliers to procure this type of fuel. They need it for their business model. The RHO should be implemented in 2026. What we see now is movement in relation to these plans being developed. We see a ramp up; we expect that to ramp up even more next year.

We got a bit of insight with the first grant where we saw those 18 plants that were already through planning and ready to break ground. That gives an indication of the volume there now. Once the renewable heat obligation comes in and the market starts to see there is long-term demand and large energy users are looking for the gas, we will see it to start to ramp up. The strategy talks about 200 plants. That is if we are to meet the 5.7 TWh target, but the roll-out and rate of development will be more staggered, but we need to make sure-----
How much approximately are they getting each? Does it depend on the size, that is, the grant they are getting?
Yes.
Is it a maximum of €5 million?

Yes, that was in the previous grant round. We are having new grant round going forward. We still have to do the terms and conditions in relation to that but there will be similarities. We want it structured in such a way that we provide additional support to smaller farm led plants.

I presume there has been an awful lot of studying done on this. The planners in local authorities depend on the Department to send out guidelines because they are not used to this. They will be looking for guidance. In the Department's vision, do the witnesses expect to see a lot of these in single farms?
That is what the Department of agriculture wants to see. It wants to see the co-operative model we brought in here, whether it is to do with feedstocks and then farmer project leads on that.
If we use the example of a town of 15,000 people - I do not want to go big - in the Department's vision, does it see one of these somewhere in the vicinity of that town?

There is no reason not to. However, what we see in regard to the trend, and what we see on the Continent, is that historically these have been smaller farm-led plants but we are now moving towards the larger commercial scale plants. They are not being built on the farm but the farmers are feeding into those plants. In terms of what the business model looks like, maybe they get a gate fee for their feedstock, or they might get the digestate in return. We are seeing mixed models in relation to that. What we are likely to see is a mix as well - commercial sized plants and farm-led plants.

The other side of it is that to own and operate a plant is a different world from the farming world where the farmer would be the expert in the feedstock. What we are trying to do as well - and we will mention it throughout the day - is that with the communications strategy we want to start looking at that. There are case studies here where a farmer can get an AD operator to come in, help them build and operate, show them how to do that and then move off site. There are lots of-----
These will be allowed to be work all year around. We will see the farmers drawing the slurries into these during the winter. Is that what the witnesses are saying?
Yes.
We will all need less capacity for storing slurry.
Exactly, that is one of the key benefits of it.
They will be selling the manure back out to the farmers.
It depends on the model that they set up. That is a possibility.
If a model is set up that cannot sell back, what do they do with the waste that comes off it?
It depends on what agreement the farmer would go in who is probably selling the feedstocks-----
We will say that farmer does not want the stuff back. When it comes out at the other end-----
They will be obliged-----
There will be a lot more than farmers. Will there be dead meat? Will knackers go out of existence now? Will all of the cattle go in there?
Sorry?
Will dead animals go in there?
No.
What cannot go in there?
It would be strict what can go into it. That would be regulated through the animal by-product regulation. They are quite sensitive pieces of infrastructure.
As a farmer, could I bring slurry into it if there was one beside me?
Yes.
When they talk about bringing in grass, maize and everything like that, is that the company buying it off them and doing a deal?
That would be the commercial arrangement between the farmer and company doing it. We would not have involvement in it.

In regard to a town with a population of 20,000 to 30,000, can the witnesses provide me with any guidelines to tell me how much land they have to take in order to feed that? Will they be out actively in the community taking land to feed it?
We could follow up with that. There are figures. Teagasc has done great work in that space on what it would take to feed it-----

Does anyone have an answer to that? I would like to know. I live in the growing town of Portlaoise. It has over 30,000 people. If there is one of them in Portlaoise now, would the people running that have to be going around and taking land in order to feed it because they would not be getting-----
They have undertaken work to get data from Teagasc.
We can give an average of the plant.
Can the witnesses send that data back to us?
Yes, we can ask about an average size plant and what it would take.

There has to be engagement with the communities. I spend most of my time now at public meetings - at least two or three nights a week - to do with the windmills. There are huge problems out there. We need to try to come together, and everyone should get an opportunity to do that. I was on the local authority for all the county development plans for the windmills but I do not know if they are equipped at all. This was not in our previous county development plan; there was no word about this. However, there is now, and we are talking about planning permissions. From my experience in local authorities, please engage with local authorities and the planners in local authorities who have to make a decision on this on behalf of the people of the county.

I thank the witnesses for coming in. It is a little bit like putting the cart before the horse with the regulations. Like Deputy Aird, I am at so many meetings about wind turbines. We are looking back to 2007 for regulations on them. They were half the size but now they are double the size. As we have to meet our environment targets, there is absolutely no urgency to updating those regulations. Have we got regulations right now to say, from a small one to a big one, exactly what they are or are they just standards? If there were regulations on it, it would say that there is a step back distance. I get what Deputy Aird is saying as well. If there is one in a community and it is feeding from all around it, at the moment with tillage there is a fight already because of the derogations for the dairy farmer. We have heard stories about Germany where it has driven prices of land up. Our land is already expensive enough. We do not want to see it climb anymore.

People were looking for a moratorium on wind turbines until regulations were updated. I find it difficult to see how these are going. I know the Government has targets to meet. It is better to spread it around between wind, solar and everything. However, without regulations, people do not have a leg to stand on. What is happening with the wind turbines is that they are going at it at a smaller scale and then they are coming back a couple of years later. These communities have to pay out of their own pockets to try to fight these cases. In Seskin in north Kilkenny, they are back again. The community is again trying to rally together to raise more money to be able to fight it. They are coming out with stacks of paper that the ordinary Joe soap is expected to read. This cannot be another situation like that. It is the cart before the horse. We knew long before now that we had to meet environmental targets. Why are the likes of the wind farms and these regulations not updated?

We heard very little from the Government to saying, "This is where we are and these are the guidelines there at the moment." We are trying to sell it to the public that there will not be a smell. There will be a smell. When one moves slurry, there is a smell, although there is no smell off grass. They will go down rural roads.

There is a hell of a lot to do but without regulations we are absolutely at nothing. People are already struggling enough with turbines and other stuff, and we cannot expect them to deal with this as well.

The last thing we want is communities having to fight this type of infrastructure coming into their local communities. We need the project promoters working with local communities to make sure that local communities get the benefits from this type of infrastructure. That is crucial. We need a communication strategy to ensure we get out the information that is needed from all concerned stakeholders, including local communities, project promoters and developers, the regulatory authorities, and local authorities.

This sector is already heavily regulated including by the Department of agriculture and Government agencies such as the EPA, the Health and Safety Authority and the Commission for Regulation of Utilities. Obviously, people connecting into the gas network need to fulfil the requirements for gas networks.
Is there one regulation they have all fed into for these?
We need to bring them all together in one document to make it easier for local authorities to assess them.
That should be done immediately.
I have two other questions. Are the 200 plants large or is it a mixture of both?
It is a mixture of different sizes and different scales.

What is the incentive for farmers who are using grain, grass, maize or whatever they are going to use for it? The plant in north Dublin was not charging for the product that was coming out at the end; that was going to have to go back. However, it alluded to the fact that while the farmer is sending in slurry, he will have an obligation to take back X amount of it and will have to buy it back. What incentives will the Government put in place for farmers to do that? They are being good lads and doing the right thing for the environment. What incentives will they get for that?

Ultimately, the incentive is a commercial arrangement between the farmer and the developer. The Government does not have a role in that at the moment. There are no proposals or policies for funding. There is funding available for farmers potentially building these plants. However, regarding the feedstock or the offtake coming from it, that is purely a commercial arrangement between the farmer and the developer.
I do not see that as viable.
I thank the witnesses for coming in. They said earlier that the guidelines are not in place and yet we have 18 projects on the ground with no guidelines.
They would have gone through the planning process and have to get the licences.

Let us be quite clear on this: the witnesses have said the guidelines are not there yet, but we have projects that have already started without guidelines. The planning guidelines that are there at the moment are regulations. The witnesses have been asked if they work with communities and they said they hope that communities will be involved, but some of the guidelines are not there yet. There are 18 projects on the ground. What does an average 60,000 tonne project cost roughly?
I would say it in gigawatt hours so I am not-----
Would it be €20 million?
Yes, €20 million.
Twenty percent of €20 million is €4 million. Who is putting up the rest of the money? It can only be led by a developer, likely a multinational company. Is that correct?
Yes.

We will be bringing multinational companies into our country to provide us with biogas and expect our farming and urban communities to buy into this. This is what we are saying here. The witnesses have said there is a pot of roughly €40 million for this. It takes €20 million to put up one plant so we will get roughly two plants, 20% of two plants. Is that correct?
Eighteen plants were allocated funding under the first grant round. Significant extra funding has been allocated for the second grant round that will come into effect next year.
The €40 million.
The €40 million was in the first grant round. The second grant round is significantly higher but that figure has not been mentioned yet.
How much of that €40 million from the first round has been drawn down?
It has until the end of 2025.
Therefore, it has not been drawn down.
No.
Ultimately that information is with the Department of agriculture. We do not have the-----
It will not be drawn down until the end of 2025.
It has until the end. That is the funding cycle.
It has until the end of 2025, which is in two months' time.
Yes, quarter 4 of 2025. The projects would have to have installed capacity by quarter 4 of 2025 and just-----
What are the chances of those projects hitting the target there?
We do not have the progress reports from the Department of agriculture, but we could get them for the Senator.
The chances are that they will not be there because they will not have been finished.

Regarding EPA licences and one thing and another, as we discussed with the previous set of witnesses here, some EPA licence holders are already recycling the food waste and one thing and another. As they are in communities already and have an EPA licence, is there a thought process that they might be fitted on to some of these plants rather than out in communities? It already has a licence from the EPA. It is already taking in food waste. It is already taking in a product. Is there joined-up thinking to look at facilities like that which are recycling and bringing in-----
They would be two distinct licences. They would have to deal with the-----

They have EPA licences to take in waste food and other waste product. To streamline this whole thing, there should be joined-up thinking as they already have an EPA licence and are working within the conditions. Is there room to put up one of these plants on that site? It bewilders me that we are looking at multinationals coming in to build these plants. The beneficiaries of these plants will be multinationals and private investors.
I think it will be a mix. It would not be fair to say-----
We have said that the projects are not there yet for the farming community.

It would not be fair to say it will be just multinationals that will benefit. The other point to clarify is that that €40 million was from RePowerEU, from the European Union. It was also for biomethane production. The second fund will come from our Department; that is not EU funding. It is important to be clear and to note that.
Is it correct that we envisage having 200 plants?
That is what it could be, depending on a mix of different scales. To get to 5.7 TWh, it would take in the region of-----
What would be the average scale of those 200 plants?

Based on the strategy we prepared, it could be anywhere from 25 GWh upwards. However, we are seeing larger plants coming through planning. That was an estimation. To get to 5.7 TWh, it would require a mix a mix of plants to deliver that. There was a range from 25 GWh up to, I think, 80 GWh or 100 GWh.
Are the new industrial plants which are coming in at the minute around the major cities or are they off key networks like the ESB's?
Again, it is a mix.

The developer has to get a number of things. It has to be located where there is access to feedstock and it also needs to be located generally where it can get access to the gas network. That is what they base it on.
Have the plants that have the planning and everything engaged with communities? That is very important.
I need to move on. Deputy Healy-Rae has the floor.

With no disrespect to the two witnesses, it is very clear to me that the Department is pushing this through without due diligence and planning. From what I have heard, I do not think people need to go for planning permission to get one of these things built. Is that right or wrong?
No, they have to go through full planning.
Is it in the Kerry county development plan?
Is there a strict set of guidelines that says you have to be 1 km away from an existing house?
I do not believe so, no.
There are no regulation.

Not specific to biomethane. Although biomethane is recognised in the national planning framework and in the Planning and Development Act, I do not believe the specific standards the Deputy described are set out.

This is very concerning. People's homes are their castles. There are so many people without houses. I applaud the people who have built their own houses and want to ensure the value is maintained and that they do not have to suffer these things beside them. It is absolutely reprehensible that the planning regulator will stick its nose into Kerry County Council and the county development plan when we are looking to zone land to help people build houses. At the same time, it is not bothered about this.

We must meet certain targets by 2030. I did not vote for a deadline of 2030 and I never will. That is the truth. There is a figure of €5 million there for someone. We know people in small businesses are down on their knees trying to stay going until next July in the hope they will get the cut in VAT rate. I heard a figure being mentioned. We were slow to give the tillage men €50 million. We do not what they have got because I was told different figures. We were told they got €30 million and then €50 million. They were looking for €60 million. Some other crowd were going to give them €80 million and I do not know if they got any millions. This is absolutely ridiculous.

I thought biodigesters were something to help farmers if they had an excess of slurry. Most of them are compliant now because they have built slatted sheds and spent a lot of money. I thought it was to help the likes of them with small grants or to give them whatever grant was needed to get them going if they had a problem, especially with the nitrates derogation and everything. I now see that at the back of this, come hell or high water, we must have these things in place to produce a certain amount of gas, whether it is good grass that is put into them or maize, as I saw in the North of Ireland yesterday. There were tractor loads and lorry loads passing each other out going to this place to produce gas. There is a place called "Stop". This is totally different from what I thought it would be.

I mean no disrespect in the world to the witnesses, who are doing their job and they are doing it fine. That is fine by me. It is the people that sent them in here more or less saying they will engage with communities. What good is engaging with communities if they are uncertain? What good is it to have half a village or half a town complaining if this thing is landed in beside them, without a rule or law in the county development plan? The county development plan is sacrosanct to what goes on in the local authority area. Deputy Aird and I have been members of our respective local authorities, and others have been-----
The Deputy is leaving no time for an answer.
That is my concern. There does not seem to be any place for this to be thrashed out or for planners to do proper due diligence. For instance, when a fella puts in planning permission for a house-----
The Deputy is leaving no time for the witnesses to answer his question.

-----his application is sent to environmental services, water services, roads and all the different bodies to measure it and come back with an answer. The planner then makes the final decision. This is not happening in this case, is it?
I ask the witnesses to answer in the time available.

I will make just a couple of points. There will be benefits for local communities and farmers from the development of these plants, whether it is jobs, an additional income stream for the farmer or improved water quality in the local communities. There are a lot of benefits for the local community.
That did not answer my question at all.
There is no time to answer it.

Mr. Kinsella mentions jobs and all the other benefits but there is no proper planning process for this. There is no specification as to where these plants can be put or what distance they have to be from a house. Is there that stipulation in any part of the regulations?
I am not aware of one specifically in relation to distance from housing but full planning permission is needed to get these plants built.
As with any build. The Deputy touched on a couple of points there-----
I know our senior planners look at what they have to adhere to but it is not appearing here.
Will the Deputy give the witnesses an opportunity to answer?
I am sorry.

It is important to note there is good engagement and there is poor engagement. At the previous meeting, a couple of members said there was little to no engagement or there was direct engagement at a house. That has to change. There were no objections to the plant in Ballinrobe, according to the Nephin Energy representatives when they were before the committee. It is our job to start engaging with developers to tell them the best way to do this. On the other side-----
There is no compulsion on them to do that at all. They can say they met a couple of fellas down the road who agreed with it but there is no account of the fellas who were against it.
We need to move on to Senator Collins.
I thank the witnesses very much.
I thank and welcome the witnesses. I will be very brief. I have two or three questions. Is there a timeline for when the guidelines will be put together into one document?
No.
There is no timeline, okay.
That has started, though.
Should the EPA get more resources before any more plants are given planning permission?
I think it had to be done the minute we published the strategy.
Has that process started?
We are already engaging with the key agencies to see what their current resourcing allocations are now.
Brilliant.
We are asking what they believe they might need given the volume of plants that we could see. We are not seeing this volume of plants but we are trying to get ahead of that and be prepared for it.

I can tell the witnesses that the community engagement is not up to par. I know the community engagement meeting for County Limerick happened in County Cork. They would not even have it in the same area. I know of some companies that will say they will do community engagement and go out to each individual house but if they are invited to a public meeting, they will not turn up because they do not want to be in front of too many people. They want to approach people about this individually. When something seems dodgy, people will think something is going on. Of the 18 plants we already have, how many went to An Bord Pleanála?
All of them would have had to go through planning.
Objections were made to all of them.
Sorry, no. They all went through planning.
Yes, but how many were objected to?
All had planning permission in place because one of the criteria of the grant was that full planning permission had to be in place.
I know but does Ms Hamill know how many of the plants were objected to?
I am not sure but we could find that out.

I ask Ms Hamill to do that to see what way other communities feel. My one recommendation is that, when the next round of grants come up, the single farmer is prioritised over the industrial sites. I can see it being repeatedly objected to for industrial size because they will take over so much land. Our roads infrastructure is not up to scratch and never will be. I have been living in the countryside for nearly 40 years and the roads are still the same. The road outside my house was resurfaced 28 years ago and it probably will not be done again for another 28 years. Roads are not being kept up and there is no point in saying they will be because we know that funds do not go into the rural roads. Putting these plants in the wrong location is the first mistake that will happen. It would be nice to see those guidelines tightened up and implemented.

I have one or two quick questions. The implementation group is developing guidelines. How high level or low level does it see those guidelines being? Will they define setback distances and the type of digestate that will go in to the plants or will it be a fairly high-level concept? What level of guidelines is envisaged? The group has already started on these guidelines but they are not ready yet. When is it envisaged they will be ready?

Planning is set out in various frameworks and Acts at the moment. We want to pull all that together in one document to make it easier for local authorities when they are reviewing these types of plants. During that process, if we recognise there are gaps and missing elements, we might have to move those guidelines from a supporting document to something that has more of a statutory basis.
We will have to look at it as we go through the process.
Does that mean the Department would be releasing guidelines chapter by chapter or in one big bang?

If it appears there are gaps in current planning it will probably take longer than we expect. We would be looking at probably the end of next year or maybe into 2027. If it is guidelines or supporting documents we are providing to local authorities with existing planning in place and if we and the Department of housing are comfortable with what is in there, then we are looking at something much shorter.

It is also important to note there is a distinction between the two. The local authorities and anyone issuing licences and permitting need to start to do that with a standardised approach. Consequently, there are supporting guidelines that need to go out and they need to go out first. Then, as Mr. Kinsella is saying, the delay would be if it had to take a more statutory function. That is where it would have to come into the more regulatory side.
When would the officials envisage those?
It is being worked on now. We are looking to give a timeline now.
If it does not go into the statutory field, we should be able to deliver in the first half of next year.
On the feedstock, the officials are not talking about starting with grass but with food waste, slurries and so on. At some point we will reach a threshold when we will be looking towards grass.

As the economics are more there on the waste base, it is more that a developer would choose to go with the waste that is already there and is more readily available. We need to see more farmers coming. We need to mobilise that sector to grow the feedstock. That is where we will be looking to get to the 5.7 TWh, but in the early days and especially with the plants we see going through that first grant, it will be more waste-based.
Do any of the plants that are operating flare off gas?
I am not expert in that.
No, I am not able to provide an answer but we can look into it.
I would appreciate it if the officials could.
In the time we have left, we will do a quickfire round. I have Senator Daly, Deputy Fitzmaurice and Deputy Aird.

I have a couple of questions. Maybe we will go into any other business. It is not a private meeting but I propose we visit the plant in Deputy Fitzmaurice's locality at some stage to see it. We have heard a lot about it but we have to see it in action. Is it to do with Brendan Gildea, who was here?
Brendan Gildea.
As we do not have a private meeting for a couple of weeks, I propose that we go as a committee.

Coming back to the officials, after listening to what I have heard, and especially what Deputy Healy-Rae said, I am a farmer too and I am thinking like him. I am thinking of the slurry and the digestate and not of the biogas. Is it fair to say we are starting at the 5.7 TWh commitment and working back? Do people get an allowance? We will use Brendan Gildea as an example. How does he fit into the 5.7 TWh? The gas he is producing is not going to Gas Networks Ireland. If he is burning that on the farm to produce his electricity but he never bought gas before, is there an allowance for everyone, even if it is small, off that 5.7 TWh? That is the first question.

Again thinking as a farmer, what is the Irish policy or situation with recovered nitrogen from manure, RENURE? If a farmer builds one of these and is putting the digestate out on the land, does that or does it not count towards his 170 kg/ha in the nitrates directive?
On the 5.7 TWh, all size plants would feed into that. The 5.7 TWh is production of biomethane, it is not-----
Irrespective of where it is used.
Yes, exactly.

On the RENURE, it is probably better for the Department of agriculture to answer that question as I am not 100% sure. The ultimate aim with digestate from anaerobic digestion plants is to support it in relation to the nitrates directive and feed into that RENURE element. As for where that has landed at the moment, the Department of agriculture is discussing that with the European Commission and we would have to reach out to that Department to get more information on that topic.

On the 18 plants that are in place at the moment, we are eight weeks from Christmas and surely to God, if the officials have a purse that is to be paid out they have checked it out. I have a fair clue about what is going on around the country in AD and I cannot see too many of those 18 plants being ready for Christmas. What indication have the officials?
The Department of agriculture carries out the property calls so we would be able to request that.
What has the Department told Ms Hamill and Mr. Kinsella up to now?
Not all of those plants are going to be-----
How many will be? How many do the officials expect? Will it be half of them?
We do not have an exact number.
Will it be a quarter of them?
We can furnish the most recent property calls.
I ask them to forward that to the committee.

How come under the policy if I put up my own anaerobic digester like Brendan Gildea did there is no hassle with the EPA or any of that, but if a group of us farmers get together with the same thing called slurry, because we do it in a community we have to use the EPA even though it is the slurry out of four or five farms together? That is even though it is going through anaerobic digestion.
I was surprised at that one. I went down to visit the Grange plant and I was told that once an animal by-product from multiple farms is coming in, it is subject to all the environmental regulation.
Yes, but is anyone going to look at that or change it? That is what I am asking.
Again, we can discuss it with the Department of agriculture.
Previous speakers spoke about odour. In my opinion, if an anaerobic digester runs right there is not an odour, but how is odour measured? I can never fathom that.
I think one of the developers touched on that as well. It is a very hard thing to say because what might smell to me might not smell to somebody else.
Yes, but is there any way to measure odour? I do not think so.

I do not believe so but I have visited a plant and they are very professional in how they do that. They have the negative air when you go in and out. There are ways of minimising that and they are learning from other EU developers and producers to minimise that. We are starting from that point, I suppose, but I am not aware of any way to measure odour.
Will the officials come back to the committee with the figures as soon as possible on the 18 plants the €40 million is there for?
Yes, we can request the most recent progress report.

Will the officials tell us where the 18 are located and whether they have planning permission? My second point is that when Brendan Gildea was in here, his job was completely different to any other job. That was a private job on his farm. He is taking in nothing from anyone else. He is burning his own slurry and throwing straw into it as well. If there is a digester in the town of Portlaoise, what can come into it? I am told all the waste on the waste lorries is coming into them, such as household waste from the brown bins. That is grand and can be understood but is ordinary waste going into it? Can everything go into this?
No, and I think-----
What can go into it?

They are very sensitive infrastructure and what goes in directly affects the quality of the gas. The likes of brown bin waste cannot go in because of the way we do not separate our garden and food waste.
What did the officials see when they went out there?

That was industrial food waste. It is completely different. There has to be unpacking. You could have food waste, then the energy crops, slurries and a mix of different ones. You could not put, say, black bin waste in there as that is a slightly different form of an anaerobic-----
The waste from the brown bins that are all around the country now for food waste will go into it.
My understanding is they cannot because we do not separate our food waste from our garden waste in our brown bins.
Then where are they going to get the stuff?
It will primarily come from slurry. Slurry will form the bulk of what is provided to produce biomethane. That will be the primary feedstock going into the AD plants.
And there is the industrial food waste.
Then they are not suitable for a town. Why would you bring slurry in from the countryside into the middle of a town? Let us be fair about this. It is getting worse as we talk about it.
These primarily will not be located in towns. We see in Europe they can be located in towns or close to towns-----
We will not want the lorries coming in.
-----but primarily they will be located-----
They will be out in the country.
Yes.
For access to the feedstocks.
On the question of planning and designation, we will have to go back to the county development plan. If you are out in the middle of the country how do you get planning?
We need to bring in Deputy Newsome Drennan.
You cannot do it.
At the moment it is 20% for the grant.
Yes.
In other European countries that is a lot more. It is 40% or 60% in some situations. Can we see that moving?
State aid obviously has to be looked at in terms of the level of grant and then maybe there is a tiered grant that would be awarded. That is what we have to look at now.
Was it €40 million from European funding?
That was the total cost.
Is that the total for a year or for so many projects?

That was the first grant round. There were 18 projects that went into that and that was 20% support up to a maximum of €5 million. We will now go into a second round. There has been significant additional funding provided for that round.

We are looking at the detailed terms and conditions now. Will we go with what was done in the first round or will we go with something a bit more or a bit less? However, what we want to look at is how we support those smaller farm-led projects in this grant round.

Of the 18 projects that are planned or are in the process of being built, how many are small farmers or small yards or how many are the bigger plants? How much international money or investors have gone into those 18 projects?

They are a mix of different sizes. There were different owner operators as well. Again, we can look at that and see what we could provide. Obviously, there would be confidential commercial sensitivities around that information.
I would not need to know the company in particular but just whether it was international or not.

I know the Deputy asked for that as well, so we can furnish that and where the locations of the plants are and the production levels they would have. We can see if we can overlay that with the investment.
I thank Ms Hamill.
I call Senator Collins.
I have a quick question on the EPA. The officials say it has powers. Has it the powers to compel a closure while an investigation is under way if the plant is not up to standard?
I do not have the information. I am not sure whether it can close it down or not.
Is that something we can look into?
Yes, we can look into that and come back. I know a question was asked about the type of complaint that is there at the moment.

Yes, if they were not up to standard and only the EPA could take them to court, they could still be seeping out or whatever the issue is could be ongoing for a year or two while the case is being looked at. It would be nice to know if the EPA could get those powers.

I know it was mentioned in the previous session around methane leakage, there is an action in the strategy to look at that. We have been engaging with Denmark which was mentioned. It brought that in. It was voluntary at the start and I think it has put more of a statutory function on it. We are engaged with them to see what that looks like where the onus would be on the plant to send in an audit report of that and then we could go in and have a look but again it is a question of who regulates that, how is it regulated and the level of regulation that goes into it. We are looking at that.
I thank Ms Hamill.
Is there another question?
When grass, food waste and whatever is brought in and that end product goes back out, it is in liquid form. It does not go back out in pellet form.
I think there is solid and liquid. It depends, does it not?

However, in most of the plants at the moment, what is going out is in liquid form. On water quality, would it not be viable and feasible that it be put in pellet form? As the witnesses know, when it goes out in liquid form, it can run off whereas in pellet form it has to digest down. I would like the figures from the plants for 2026 and where we are at with them.

Unless there is buy-in from the farming communities and small-scale farms are willing to do this, you cannot go with large-scale all over Ireland. I do not think that will be feasible because there has to be something more in it than a contractor going out to cut grass and bringing it into a plant. The farmer has to have more than that benefit from it for this to work. The only way it will work, whether it generates gas or electricity, is for the farmer to see a benefit out of it. That is my opinion of the Department's policies, guidelines and regulations. That is something it needs to look at. If it is led by farmers and communities, then it has some chance of getting this across the line. Otherwise, it will see mass objections from bigger communities regarding the large-scale.

It is the starting point. We have talked about the communications strategy but we have not really said what it looks like. There are three strands to it. It is exactly as the Senator is saying. We need that buy-in from farmers. We need to show them, and educate them of, the benefits and the supports that are available. The other side is the developer side. We need to start streamlining what they are doing and how they are communicating case studies and best practice. The other strand is the local communities and where these plants will be built. They are all interdependent on each other. We need farmers to grow the feedstocks; we need supports and investment security for the project developers; we need to be able to move them through planning very quickly, or more quickly than at present; when they getting into the planning side, we need to be able to make sure communities are secure enough and the information being given to them by ourselves is valid; and at the end, we need to say where we are going to put this valuable resource. We need to direct it to the best-end resource. Each one of those is a key feature and they are all interdependent. If you take one away, you do not have your gas.

My understanding is that it is not viable at the moment to pellet it. It needs too much energy, so what is the solution? If you talk about water quality, pelleting will be paramount to that. Where are you going then if that is not viable? There needs to be a good feed-in tariff, although I know what went on in the North was a mess. It would be interesting to see the figure that comes back to the Department. That will tell its own story.

I thank members and witnesses for their extensive engagement. Gabhaim buíochas. There are a number of points the officials are to come back to the committee on. If there are any other aspects they wanted to raise that were not asked, they could include that.
There might be a few more bits we can add.
Please do. At the next meeting, we will discuss the post-2027 Common Agricultural Policy.
